Climate change poses a significant threat to our daily lives, with extreme events and climatic variations impacting crop yields. Crop production is highly vulnerable to fluctuations in climatic factors such as temperature, precipitation, soil moisture, and other factors. Recent studies emphasize the need to adapt agricultural practices in response to climate change, which requires predicting how climate changes will affect crop yields. Crop yield prediction can contribute to food security, supply stability, seed breeding, and economic planning.

However, crop yield depends on numerous complex factors, including temperature, precipitation, soil moisture, soil type, and others. To model these complex relationships, machine learning methods have been widely adopted in crop yield prediction. Despite the large number of papers in this area, many share similar methods. Among the surveyed papers, around 70% used neural networks, 14% used tree-based methods, and 14% used linear regressions. These methods often differ in location (US, Brazil, India), study granularity (province, county, site/farm), crop types (soybean, corn), and time range (weeks to years).

Most machine learning methods treat each county as an independent sample, ignoring spatial correlations in the data. For instance, if one county has a high yield, neighboring counties are likely to have high yields as well, violating the independence assumption. We introduce a novel graph-based recurrent neural network (GNN-RNN) that incorporates both geographical and temporal structure into crop yield prediction.

Our method is trained, validated, and tested on over 2000 counties from 41 US states, covering years from 1981 to 2019. This is the first machine learning method to embed geographical knowledge in crop yield prediction and predict crop yields at the county level nationwide. Experimental results show that our proposed method consistently outperforms a wide variety of existing state-of-the-art methods, validating the effectiveness of geospatial and temporal information.

Our GNN-RNN model integrates geospatial and temporal knowledge by using graph neural networks (GNNs) synergistically with recurrent neural networks (RNNs). We compare our GNN-RNN method with a wide array of machine learning methods on a nationwide scale and show that our novel model can achieve superior performance on multiple nationwide benchmarks, consistently outperforming existing methods by 10% on both RMSE and R2. Our work is the first to incorporate geographical knowledge into crop yield prediction, and we show that doing so significantly improves prediction accuracy.

In crop yield prediction, we denote each county's climatic features by xc;t and ground-truth crop yield by yc;t, where c and t represent county and year, respectively. Each xc;t contains four types of features: weather features xw c;t, land surface features xl c;t, soil quality features xs c, and extra features xe c. The features are described in the Appendix.
